title: Shimano recalls 760,000 Dura-Ace and Ultegra cranks after thousands of failures
content:
Cyclist
Shimano recalls 760,000 Dura-Ace and Ultegra cranks after thousands of failures

Shimano has issued a recall of specific 11-speed Ultegra and Dura-Ace cranksets, explaining that the bonded cranks can separate and break, posing a crash risk to users.

This recall, published by the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission, involves Shimano Ultegra FC-6800, Dura-Ace FC-9000, Ultegra FC-R8000, Dura-Ace FC-R9100 and FC-R9100P 11-Speed Bonded Hollowtech II cranksets.

The affected models were produced pre-July 2019 and have the following two letter production code on backside of the crank arm, just next to where the pedals are attached: KF, KG, KH, KI, KJ, KK, KL, LA, LB, LC, LD, LE, LF, LG, LH, LI, LJ, LK, LL, MA, MB, MC, MD, ME, MF, MG, MH, MI, MJ, MK, ML, NA, NB, NC, ND, NE, NF, NG, NH, NI, NJ, NK, NL, OA, OB, OC, OD, OE, OF, OG, OH, OI, OJ, OK, OL, PA, PB, PC, PD, PE, PF, PG, PH, PI, PJ, PK, PL, QA, QB, QC, QD, QE, QF, QG, QH, QI, QJ, QK, QL, RA, RB, RC, RD, RE, and RF.

Since 2012, about 680,000 of the faulty cranksets have been sold as original equipment on bikes and after market in the US alone, plus 80,000 in Canada and an as-yet unknown number in other parts of the world.

If users are in possession of an at-risk crankset, they are advised to stop riding them immediately and contact an authorized Shimano dealer to schedule a free inspection. The recall initially only applied to owners of the faulty cranksets in the US, but has since been rolled out into Europe, with further territories to folllow.

Update 17:18 BST: Shimano has put together a detailed guide for riders worried about their cranks.

However, only consumers whose cranksets show signs of bonding separation or delamination during the inspection will be provided a free replacement crankset and installation, and replacements will consist of adjusted current generation cranksets paired with 11-speed chainrings, as opposed to a like-for-like replacement.

Users with affected power-equipped cranks will receive the same approved replacements along with a voucher to offset the cost of replacing the meter.

Should the cranks fit the production criteria but not show signs of fault, users are free to carry on riding them, albeit with the advice to regularly inspect them. Whether they will feel comfortable with the is another matter.

As covered by our website editor Matthew Loveridge in a previous life, this has been recognised as an unofficial issue for some time, with social media accounts documenting the recurring (albeit relatively uncommon) failure mode.

Shimano has reportedly received 4,519 incidents of cranksets separating, resulting in six injuries that include ‘bone fractures, joint displacement and lacerations’. While that absolute number is high, due to the volume these cranksets have been sold in the figure represents a less than 1% failure rate.

author: Sam Challis | Tech Editor
